questions.neutral: You know your way around down here?

hobby.message: Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?
Analog photography still treating you right?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Lived here long enough, I suppose.
Not much to say about that. Just keep to myself, usually.
I fold paper. Origami. Simple distraction.
Harder lately with, well, everything shut down.
I know my way enough to find quiet corners.
Mostly just stay busy with origami. Keeps my hands steady.
Not really into crowds or noise down here.
The power flickers interrupted my projects last week.
Folding in low light isn’t ideal, really.
Yeah, I know the place. Been here a while.
Origami’s my thing. Complex models, not just cranes.
Had to fold from old system notices during those outages.
Kind of funny. Old authority messages turning into art.
An evening folding helps me think, even when systems crash.
People seem to appreciate these small distractions lately.
I’ve learned the ins and outs, mostly by avoiding attention.
Origami’s more than a pastime—tessellation, modular pieces, sometimes my own designs.
That system blackout? Forced me to improvise with scraps.
Sometimes I trade folded stars for favors or news.
It’s strange—paper lotus in the window has become a signal lately.
Back in the day, I’d teach folding workshops for neighbors.
With the new restrictions, people hide what they love.
Know my way, yes—born here, used to sneak into closed blocks as a teen.
Origami’s been my anchor since before the BCI days. Complex modulars, tessellations, even wet folding.
The system failures—lights out, network gone—pushed me to use old BCI notices as paper.
Funny, folding what once tracked us into something harmless. In the blackout, it was all by memory.
Last week, I saw a neighbor’s daughter hiding paper cranes in the stairwell—quiet resistance.
Sometimes, I sketch folding patterns over encrypted files, just for the puzzle.
Used to share models openly, before the score drops. Now? You never know who’s watching.
Feels subversive now, finding peace in a crease, but I’m not sure I’d give it up.
hobby_answer: Yes. Still folding, when I can.
Mostly basic models lately—nothing fancy.
Materials are harder to get since patrols began.
Sometimes power cuts make it impossible.
Used to relax me, now it's just habit.
Still folding, yeah. Helps with the noise.
Hard now—lost access to my online diagrams.
City outages mean I work from memory, mostly.
People notice me using scrap from BCI notices.
Feels more exposed since the new restrictions.
Yeah, origami keeps me steady.
These days I'm folding by candle or window light.
No diagrams since the network outages—just old folds from memory.
I use whatever paper's left, even government forms.
It distracts me when BCI scores jump around so much.
Kind of ironic, really—my hobby's almost a protest now.
I saw a neighbor folding too, during last week’s blackout.
Definitely still folding. It's the one thing I rely on.
BCI outages made me switch from tutorials to mental patterns.
I had to use old Directorate reports—seeing the text as I fold feels strange.
Power failures slow me down, but I keep going, even in the dark.
Last week, during the patrol crackdowns, I shared a paper crane with a neighbor.
People seem drawn to small routines—especially now that everything official is falling apart.
We folded quietly together, just for a moment.
It makes the enforced silence feel less sharp.
Always, yes. Origami keeps me anchored, especially now.
After Halden died and power started cutting out, everything changed.
My diagrams were locked behind authorization errors—so I switched to internal designs.
Sometimes I use old flagged reports as paper. Feels subversive, even if it's not much.
When Directorate teams raided our block, I hid a few folded stars—habit, I guess.
During the network blackout, a neighbor and I traded models through the back stairwell.
We barely spoke, but the exchange said enough in this city.
Folding was just for focus before, now it’s connection—quiet resistance, maybe.
I never thought the system would make something so small feel dangerous.
